<Summary source="https://www.cdc.gov/fluview/surveillance/2025-week-51.html">
## Summary of CDC Influenza Surveillance Report (Week 51, 2025–26 Season)

**Note:** This article appears to be a CDC FluView weekly surveillance report, not the specific CDC Flu Burden page referenced in the resolution criteria. It does not contain cumulative hospitalization burden estimates directly relevant to the resolution question.

---

### Key Surveillance Data Points (Week 51)

**Laboratory Activity:**
- Percent positivity for influenza increased nationally and in **all 10 HHS regions** compared to Week 50 (change of ≥0.5 percentage points)
- **Region 8** had the highest positivity rate: **34.9%**
- **Region 9** had the lowest: **10.8%**
- Predominant strain: **Influenza A(H3N2)**
- **457 influenza viruses** have been genetically characterized since September 28, 2025

**Outpatient ILI Surveillance:**
- Nationally, **6.0%** of outpatient visits during Week 51 were due to ILI (fever plus cough or sore throat)

**Avian Influenza (H5N1):**
- No new confirmed human H5N1 infections reported this week
- No human-to-human transmission identified in the U.S.

**Antiviral Susceptibility:**
- High adamantane resistance persists among H1N1pdm09 and H3N2 viruses (adamantanes not recommended for treatment)
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.cdc.gov/flu-burden/php/data-vis/index.html">
## Summary of CDC Estimated US Flu Disease Burden Page (November 21, 2025)

**Source:** CDC Flu Burden page, dated November 21, 2025

### Key Points:

**Methodology:**
- CDC uses **mathematical models** to estimate flu's population impact, as exact figures are impossible to determine
- Not all flu-infected individuals seek medical care or get tested, necessitating modeled estimates
- CDC estimates cover: **illnesses, medical visits, hospitalizations, and deaths**

**Purpose of Estimates:**
- Used to **inform policy and communications** related to influenza prevention and control
- Provides population-level burden estimates for the US

---

### ⚠️ Disclaimer:
The extracted content appears to be **incomplete**. The article provides only the general methodology and purpose description for CDC's flu burden estimation program. It does **not** contain:
- Any specific numerical estimates for the 2025–26 season
- Hospitalization ranges or upper/lower bounds
- Any in-season preliminary estimates relevant to the resolution criteria of the forecast question

This appears to be background/introductory content from the CDC flu burden page rather than the specific **"Preliminary Estimated Flu Disease Burden 2025–2026 Flu Season"** data page that would be needed to directly inform the forecast question. The forecaster should consult the specific 2025–2026 data visualization page directly for resolution-relevant figures.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.cdc.gov/flu-burden/php/php/data-vis/2025-2026.html">
## Summary: CDC Preliminary Estimated Flu Disease Burden 2025–2026 Season (November 21, 2025)

### Key Facts & Statistics

- **Data coverage start:** October 1, 2025 (beginning of the 2025–26 flu season)
- **Update frequency:** Weekly, during flu season, when sufficient data are available
- **Historical range:** Past end-of-season estimates of flu-related hospitalizations (2010–2025) have ranged from **120,000 to 710,000**
- **Surveillance network:** Flu Surv-NET covers approximately **10% of the U.S. population**

### Methodology
- CDC uses mathematical models based on lab-confirmed flu hospitalization data from Flu Surv-NET
- Estimates are presented as **ranges** (lower to upper bound) rather than point values, due to ongoing flu circulation and data limitations early in the season
- Crude hospitalization rates are adjusted for testing frequency and diagnostic test sensitivity, using **prior season data as a proxy** (real-time testing data unavailable)

### Notable Limitations
- Current-season hospitalization rates may **underestimate** true rates due to identification and reporting delays
- If testing practices have changed from prior seasons, estimates may be inaccurate
- Preliminary estimates are **finalized** once contemporary testing practice data become available and **may decrease** if testing has increased

### Contextual Note
- As of the article date (November 21, 2025), **no specific numerical estimate range** for the 2025–26 season is explicitly stated in the extracted content — only the methodology and historical context are described.

**Disclaimer:** The extracted content appears to be primarily descriptive/methodological. Specific weekly numerical estimates for the 2025–26 season may not have been fully captured in this extraction.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.cdc.gov/fluvaxview/dashboard/index.html">
## Summary: CDC Weekly Flu Vaccination Dashboard (as of February 18, 2026)

**Source:** CDC FluVaxView | **Data reference date:** February 7–18, 2026

---

### Key Vaccination Coverage Statistics

**Vaccine Distribution:**
- As of January 31, 2026, **134.8 million flu vaccine doses** have been distributed in the U.S. for the 2025–26 season.

**Children (6 months–17 years):**
- As of February 7, 2026, **47.5%** of children received a flu vaccination (95% CI: 45.9%–49.1%)
- This is **similar to last season** at the same time point (46.8%)
- An additional 4.2% of parents reported definite plans to vaccinate their child

**Adults (18+):**
- As of February 7, 2026, **46.2%** of adults reported receiving a flu vaccination (95% CI: 45.2%–47.3%)
- This is **higher than last season** at the same time point (44.3%)
- An additional 5.5% reported definite plans to vaccinate

**Medicare Beneficiaries (65+):**
- As of November 29, 2025, **41.8%** of Medicare fee-for-service beneficiaries were vaccinated
- Highest coverage: non-Hispanic Asian (44.3%); Lowest: Hispanic (23.7%)

---

### Relevance to Forecasting Question
This article covers **vaccination rates only** and contains **no data on flu-related hospitalizations or disease burden estimates**. It does not directly inform the CDC's preliminary hospitalization burden estimates relevant to the resolution question.
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.nbcnews.com/health/health-news/flu-season-virus-symptoms-surge-nationwide-variants-vaccines-children-rcna251534">
## Summary: "Flu is surging nationwide, and doctors say we're nowhere near the peak" (NBC News, December 30, 2025)

### Key Statistics (as of week ending December 20, 2025):
- Flu activity at **"high" or "very high" levels in 32 states and jurisdictions**, up from 17 the prior week
- **At least 7.5 million** people have gotten sick since the season began in October
- **Hospitalizations nearly doubled** in a single week: **19,053** (up from 9,944 the prior week)
- Approximately **3,100 deaths** from flu this season
- **5 pediatric deaths**, up from 2 the prior week

### Expert Opinions:
- **Dr. Daniel Kuritzkes (Mass General Brigham):** The trajectory shows a "pretty sharp increase" that is "not anywhere close to peaking or leveling off"; expects illnesses to continue rising for several weeks, not leveling off until end of January or possibly February
- **Dr. Jennifer Goebel (South Shore University Hospital/Northwell):** Flu cases began surging around Thanksgiving; "I don't remember seeing flu cases this early and in this many numbers"
- **Dr. Donald Yealy (UPMC):** Describes a "dramatic uptick" over the past two weeks, predominantly Influenza A; vast majority of those requiring hospitalization are **unvaccinated**
- **Dr. Lauren Siewny (Duke University Hospital):** Hospital beds are tight due to overlapping COVID, RSV, and flu cases
- **Dr. Molly Fleece (University of Alabama at Birmingham):** Symptoms are similar to prior seasons but can be more severe in unvaccinated individuals

### Dominant Strain:
- **Influenza A H3N2, "subclade K"** — a mutated strain that emerged over the summer, making it harder for the immune system to recognize; associated with severe early flu seasons in the **UK and Japan**
- **WHO's Dr. Wenqing Zhang** noted current data do **not** suggest increased disease severity from the new strain

### Vaccine Effectiveness:
- This year's flu shot includes an H3N2 component but does **not perfectly match** the mutated subclade K strain (mutation occurred after vaccine selection)
- Doctors emphasize the vaccine remains effective at **preventing severe illness, hospitalization, and death**

### Co-circulating Viruses:
- COVID infections slowly increasing, particularly in the South, Northeast, and Midwest
- Norovirus remains high and rising
- RSV beginning to surge, especially in the South
</Summary>

<Summary source="https://www.cdc.gov/fluview/surveillance/2026-week-06.html">
## Summary of CDC Influenza Surveillance Article

**Note:** This article appears to be from CDC's weekly FluView surveillance report for the 2025–26 season. It does **not** contain data from the specific CDC Flu Burden page referenced in the resolution criteria (the "Preliminary Estimated Flu Disease Burden 2025–2026" page). No cumulative hospitalization burden estimates or ranges are provided in this article.

---

### Key Surveillance Findings:

**Laboratory Data:**
- Overall percentage of respiratory specimens testing positive for influenza **increased** nationally week-over-week (change >0.5 percentage points)
- Influenza A percent positivity **decreased**; Influenza B percent positivity **continues to increase**
- **Influenza A(H3N2)** was the most frequently reported virus nationally and across all HHS regions

**Regional Activity:**
- Increased in HHS Regions 2, 4, 5, 6, 7, and 8
- Decreased in Regions 1, 9, and 10
- Stable in Region 3

**Antiviral Resistance:**
- Some resistance detected: 3 A(H1N1)pdm09 viruses with oseltamivir/peramivir resistance; 7 with reduced oseltamivir inhibition; 2 B viruses with reduced peramivir inhibition
- High adamantane resistance persists among influenza A viruses

**Avian Influenza:** No new confirmed human H5N1 infections reported; no human-to-human transmission identified in the U.S.

**Genetic Characterization:** CDC has characterized **1,887 influenza viruses** collected since September 28, 2025.
</Summary>

Query: Will CDC’s preliminary estimate of cumulative flu-related hospitalizations for the 2025–26 season reach 850,000 before April 5, 2026?
Here are the relevant news articles:

**Norovirus, Enterovirus, and B-Type Flu All on the Rise: CDC Warns of Potential Small Peak**
According to the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) in Taiwan, emergency department visits for influenza-like illnesses and diarrhea rose by approximately 3% on the sixth day of the Lunar New Year compared to the previous day. On that day, influenza-like illness visits reached about 2,422, up 3.2% from 2,348 the day before, and diarrhea visits reached about 2,402, up 2.7% from 2,338. Compared to the same Lunar New Year dates over the past three years, influenza-like illness visits were 33.1% lower than in 2025, 6.6% lower than in 2024, and 35.1% higher than in 2023. Diarrhea visits were 37.9% lower than in 2025, 101% higher than in 2024, and 93.2% higher than in 2023. CDC spokesperson Lin Ming-cheng stated that after school reopens, outbreaks of norovirus clusters and enterovirus may rise, and the influenza strain has shifted, with B-type influenza increasing and A-type decreasing, showing a 'B-increase, A-decrease' trend. Lin warned that B-type influenza may surpass A-type in prevalence within the next one to two weeks, raising the risk of reinfection. The CDC emphasized that norovirus, enterovirus, and influenza are closely linked to personal hygiene. Since alcohol-based disinfectants are less effective against norovirus and enterovirus, proper handwashing with soap is recommended. Older adults, children, and those with weakened immunity should wear masks and monitor their health when visiting crowded places.
Original language: zh
Publish date: February 23, 2026 07:45 AM
Source:[ETtoday健康雲](https://health.ettoday.net/news/3121787)

**Diarrhea Outbreaks Rise Amid Concerns Over Norovirus, B-Flu, and Enterovirus Post-Lunar New Year**
The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) in Taiwan reported a continuous rise in diarrhea-related cases since the first week of 2026, with norovirus accounting for over 80% of cases. Although influenza cases are declining, the proportion of type B influenza (B-flu) is rapidly increasing and is approaching that of type A. The CDC noted that the recent holiday period created a 'group transition phase,' increasing the risk of outbreaks in workplaces and schools. On February 22, 2026, there were approximately 2,402 emergency department visits for diarrhea—up 2.7% from the previous day and 101% higher than the same period in 2023, though still lower than the same period in 2024. For influenza, emergency visits totaled about 2,422, a 3.2% increase from the previous day and a 33.1% decrease compared to the same day in 2024. The CDC's Deputy Director, Lin Ming-cheng, emphasized that norovirus is highly contagious and urged the public to practice preventive measures, including proper handwashing with soap, avoiding cross-contamination in food preparation, and disinfecting surfaces and clothing with diluted bleach. He also warned that B-flu is on the verge of surpassing A-flu, with B-flu increasing from 28% to 38.1% and A-flu decreasing from 68% to 59.5% after the Lunar New Year. Additionally, enterovirus cases are expected to rise after the holiday season, with peak incidence typically occurring around the Dragon Boat Festival and declining after summer vacation. The CDC reiterated the importance of hygiene and preventive practices during this high-risk period.
Original language: zh
Publish date: February 23, 2026 05:55 AM
Source:[中時新聞網](https://www.chinatimes.com/realtimenews/20260223002368-260405)

**Post-Lunar New Year School Return: CDC Warns of Norovirus, Enterovirus Outbreaks and Flu Shift to Type B**
The Taiwan Centers for Disease Control (CDC) reported that emergency department visits for influenza-like illness and diarrhea increased by approximately 3% compared to the previous day. On February 22, 2026, influenza-like illness emergency visits reached about 2,400 cases, a 3.2% increase from the prior day, and were 33.1% lower than the same lunar calendar date in 2025, 6.6% lower than in 2024, but 35.1% higher than in 2023. Diarrhea emergency visits also reached approximately 2,400 cases, up 2.7% from the previous day, and were 37.9% lower than in 2025, but 101% higher than in 2024 and 93.2% higher than in 2023. CDC spokesperson Lin Ming-cheng warned that three infectious diseases are of concern after the Lunar New Year: norovirus, which often causes outbreaks in schools after the break; enterovirus, which may rise in incidence; and influenza, where type B is expected to surpass type A in prevalence within the next one to two weeks, increasing the risk of reinfection. The CDC emphasized that norovirus and enterovirus are not killed by alcohol, urging the public to use soap and water for handwashing to prevent multiple infections. High-risk groups, including the elderly and young children, should wear masks in crowded places. The government has allocated NT$1.6 billion to incentivize primary care clinics to open during the holiday, and special outpatient clinics were established to reduce emergency department congestion, alleviating the overcrowding seen in previous years.
Original language: zh
Publish date: February 23, 2026 05:25 AM
Source:[UDN](https://udn.com/news/story/7266/9339212)

**Back-to-School and Back-to-Work Alert: Preventing Flu and Norovirus Outbreaks Amid Rising Travel Risks**
Following the 9-day spring break, schools and workplaces are reopening, prompting health authorities to issue warnings about potential resurgence of infectious diseases. The Taiwan Centers for Disease Control (CDC) reported that while influenza cases declined during the Lunar New Year period, B-type influenza is increasingly replacing A-type, with community prevalence nearly equal. With increased social interactions post-holidays, the risk of outbreaks in schools and group settings remains high. According to CDC Deputy Director Lin Ming-cheng, outpatient visits for influenza-like illness dropped to 2,069 on the fifth day of the Lunar New Year, a 19.5% decrease from the previous day (2,571), and significantly lower than the same period in the past three years—61% lower than 2025 (5,303), 38.3% lower than 2024 (3,351), and 4.9% lower than 2023 (2,175). Despite the decline, vigilance is still required. In addition to influenza, dengue prevention remains critical, with 10 imported cases reported by February 6, 2026, primarily from Indonesia, the Philippines, and Vietnam. The CDC urges schools to maintain mosquito control and promote proper handwashing. For travelers to Japan and South Korea, the CDC warns of ongoing outbreaks: South Korea reported 709 norovirus cases in week 5 (January 25–31), the highest in five years, while Japan saw the highest rate of infectious gastroenteritis in a decade, with an average of 9.42 cases per healthcare facility in week 5 (January 26–February 1). Norovirus is highly contagious and resistant to alcohol, with children under six being especially vulnerable. The CDC advises travelers to avoid raw foods and practice strict hand hygiene.
Original language: zh
Publish date: February 23, 2026 04:29 AM
Source:[三立新聞](https://www.setn.com/News.aspx)

**Alcohol Ineffective! Norovirus and Enterovirus May Rise in School Season – Soap and Water Are Key**
The Centers for Disease Control (CDC) in Taiwan warns that norovirus and enterovirus are still active in communities, with enterovirus cases entering an upward phase and norovirus potentially peaking at the start of the school term. The CDC emphasizes that alcohol-based hand sanitizers are ineffective against these viruses, which are non-enveloped, and that handwashing with soap is essential. According to the latest data, outpatient visits for influenza-like illness rose to 2,422 on the sixth day of the Lunar New Year, a 3.2% increase from the previous day, though still lower than in 2025 and 2024. Gastrointestinal emergency visits reached 2,402, up 2.7% from the previous day and significantly higher than in 2024 (1,195) and 2023 (1,243), indicating a rising threat. The CDC noted that emergency room congestion improved during the Lunar New Year due to outpatient分流 measures, including expanded primary care clinics and special flu clinics. However, with students returning to school, the risk of outbreaks increases. The CDC has raised the alert level for enterovirus and will initiate school and childcare facility inspections if the outbreak threshold is met. Influenza has shifted from A-type dominance to a rising trend in B-type cases, which may soon surpass A-type. The CDC recommends cleaning high-touch surfaces with a 1:1,000 bleach solution (1 capful of bleach per 1,000 cc of water) for effective disinfection.
Original language: zh
Publish date: February 23, 2026 04:29 AM
Source:[健康醫療](https://health.ltn.com.tw/article/breakingnews/5348487)

**Spring Festival Season: Influenza and Diarrhea Cases Drop, but Norovirus Threat Remains After Holiday**
According to the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) under the Ministry of Health and Welfare, acute respiratory infection and diarrhea emergency department visits in Taiwan decreased by 19.5% and 11.5% respectively on the last day of the Lunar New Year holiday (February 21, 2026), compared to the previous day. These numbers are also significantly lower than the same period last year, with a 61% drop in acute respiratory infections and a 72.5% drop in diarrhea cases. On the fifth day of the Lunar New Year, acute respiratory infection emergency visits totaled 2,069, down from 2,571 the previous day, and were 61% lower than the 5,303 visits recorded on the same day in 2025, 38.3% lower than in 2024 (3,351), and 4.9% lower than in 2023 (2,175). Diarrhea emergency visits were 2,069, a 11.5% decrease from 2,338 the day before, and 72.5% lower than the 7,524 visits on the same day in 2025, though they increased by 48.1% compared to 2024 (1,397) and 45.4% compared to 2023 (1,423). CDC spokesperson Lin Ming-cheng warned that despite the decline in cases, people should remain vigilant about norovirus and enterovirus threats as normal work and school resumes. He emphasized the importance of handwashing with soap, cooking food thoroughly, avoiding cross-contamination, and disinfecting personal items. For preventing influenza B, the CDC recommends vaccination, mask-wearing, and hand hygiene. The agency also urged travelers to monitor health, seek medical care if needed, and report recent travel history, especially regarding imported diseases such as dengue, chikungunya, measles in Southeast Asia, influenza, norovirus, and whooping cough in Northeast Asia and China, measles in Europe, malaria and parasitic infections in Africa. Additionally, sexually transmitted infections require counseling, screening, and appropriate medication assessment.
Original language: zh
Publish date: February 22, 2026 04:24 AM
Source:[UDN](https://udn.com/news/story/7266/9337568)

**Influenza-like Illness and Diarrhea Emergency Visits Drop on Lunar New Year's Fifth Day; CDC Warns of Ongoing Infectious Disease Risks**
According to the Centers for Disease Control, Department of Health, Taiwan, both influenza-like illness and diarrhea emergency department visits decreased on the fifth day of the Lunar New Year (February 22, 2026), with a total of 4,138 visits—2,069 for influenza-like illness and 2,069 for diarrhea. Influenza-like illness visits dropped 19.5% from the previous day (2,571 to 2,069), and were 61% lower than the 5,303 visits recorded on the same date in 2025, 38.3% lower than the 3,351 visits in 2024, and 4.9% lower than the 2,175 visits in 2023. Diarrhea-related emergency visits decreased by 11.5% from 2,338 to 2,069, and were 72.5% lower than the 7,524 visits in 2025, but 48.1% higher than the 1,397 visits in 2024 and 45.4% higher than the 1,423 visits in 2023. The CDC warned that despite the decline, people should remain vigilant for norovirus, enterovirus, influenza B, imported infectious diseases, and sexually transmitted infections after the holiday, especially as the workweek resumes. They urged individuals to practice good hygiene, monitor health, seek medical care if unwell, and report travel or exposure history.
Original language: zh
Publish date: February 22, 2026 04:19 AM
Source:[ETtoday健康雲](https://health.ettoday.net/news/3121292)

**Spring Festival's Last Day: Flu Cases Decline, But Norovirus and Enterovirus Remain a Concern**
On the final day of the Lunar New Year holiday, Taiwan's Centers for Disease Control (CDC) reported a decline in influenza activity, with outpatient visits for influenza-like illnesses dropping to 2,069 cases—down 19.5% from the previous day and the lowest level in four years for this period. This is significantly lower than the same dates in 2023 (2,175), 2024 (3,351), and 2025 (5,303), indicating a notable decrease in flu transmission. However, B-type influenza is increasingly replacing A-type, with community prevalence now roughly equal, and some frontline physicians note B-type cases may be surpassing A-type. The CDC warns that the post-holiday return to work and school may trigger a resurgence, similar to trends observed in Japan. Additionally, gastrointestinal illnesses remain a concern, with diarrhea-related emergency visits at 2,069—down 11.5% from the previous day but still higher than in 2023 and 2024. The CDC urges the public to continue practicing preventive measures, including handwashing, thorough cooking of food, vaccination, mask-wearing, and disclosing travel history. They also emphasize vigilance against sexually transmitted infections, recommending screening and medical evaluation for protection.
Original language: zh
Publish date: February 22, 2026 03:08 AM
Source:[健康醫療](https://health.ltn.com.tw/article/breakingnews/5347636)

**Attacks on Sudan healthcare facilities killed 69 this year: WHO**
The World Health Organization (WHO) reported that 69 people have been killed in five attacks on healthcare facilities in Sudan during the first 50 days of 2026, with 49 others injured. WHO Director-General Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus confirmed these figures on X, noting a hospital attack in Sennar state that killed three patients and wounded seven, including a staff member. Earlier in the month, three other attacks in South Kordofan resulted in over 30 deaths. Since the war began in April 2023, the WHO has documented at least 206 attacks on medical facilities, leading to approximately 2,000 deaths and hundreds of injuries. In 2025 alone, 65 attacks killed over 1,620 people, accounting for 80% of global deaths linked to attacks on healthcare. The ongoing civil war, now entering its fourth year, has caused tens of thousands of deaths and displaced 11 million people, creating one of the world’s worst humanitarian crises. The country faces multiple disease outbreaks, including cholera, malaria, dengue, and measles, alongside severe malnutrition: 4.2 million acute malnutrition cases are projected in 2026, including over 800,000 severe cases. Around 33 million people are expected to lack humanitarian aid in 2026, with the UN warning in January that aid stocks could be exhausted by the end of March.
Original language: en
Publish date: February 21, 2026 12:41 PM
Source:[AFP](http://doc.afp.com/98FR263)

**World Health Organization (WHO) Finds Next-generation Influenza Vaccines Could Save Millions of Lives by Providing Broader and Longer-lasting Protection**
According to a February 21, 2026, assessment by the World Health Organization (WHO), next-generation influenza vaccines offering broader and longer-lasting protection than current seasonal vaccines could prevent up to 18 billion influenza cases and save up to 6.2 million lives globally between 2025 and 2050. The WHO's Full Value of Improved Influenza Vaccine Assessment (FVIVA) and a related article in the journal *Vaccine* evaluate the health, economic, and policy impacts of these advanced vaccines, identifying key barriers to global uptake. Seasonal influenza causes approximately one billion infections annually, with 3 to 5 million severe cases and 290,000 to 650,000 respiratory-related deaths. Current vaccines vary in effectiveness by season, population, and product, and provide protection for only one season. Despite 143 countries reporting availability of seasonal vaccines, upper-middle and high-income nations use the majority of doses. The FVIVA estimates that widespread use of next-generation or universal vaccines could reduce unnecessary antibiotic use by up to 1.3 billion defined daily doses between 2025 and 2050, significantly contributing to global efforts against antimicrobial resistance. These vaccines are projected to remain cost-effective or even cost-saving in many countries. The WHO's Preferred Product Characteristics, updated in December 2025, emphasize broader, longer-lasting protection, better efficacy against severe disease, suitability for low- and middle-income countries (LMICs), and transferable technologies to support local manufacturing. As of February 2026, 46 next-generation influenza vaccines are in clinical development across diverse platforms, as reported by the Influenza Vaccines R&D Roadmap. The FVIVA framework supports evidence-based decision-making among governments, researchers, manufacturers, and partners, aligning with WHO’s Global Influenza Strategy 2019–2030 and the lessons learned during the COVID-19 pandemic. Dr. Philipp Lambach, WHO technical lead of the project, stated, 'It provides all those working on future influenza vaccine investments, policy development and research priorities a common set of evidence to catalyze vaccine development.'
Original language: en
Publish date: February 21, 2026 12:05 PM
Source:[Gold Rush Cam](https://www.goldrushcam.com/sierrasuntimes/index.php/news/local-news/75697-world-health-organization-who-finds-next-generation-influenza-vaccines-could-save-millions-of-lives-by-providing-broader-and-longer-lasting-protection)

**CDC says 2025-26 flu season 'moderately severe' as cases hit 11 million**
The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has classified the 2025-26 flu season as 'moderately severe,' marking the first time this designation has been used. As of the final week of December 2025, the season has caused an estimated 11 million illnesses, 120,000 hospitalizations, and 5,000 deaths. This represents a significant increase from the 2024-25 season, which saw 5.3 million illnesses, 63,000 hospitalizations, and 2,700 deaths by December 28, 2024. The CDC reported 33,301 influenza patients admitted to hospitals in the week ending December 27, 2025, a sharp rise from earlier weeks. Outpatient visits for respiratory illness reached 8.2% of all health care visits, exceeding seasonal baselines. Influenza A(H3N2) remains the dominant strain, accounting for over 91% of subtyped influenza A cases, with 90.5% of 389 genetically characterized A(H3N2) viruses belonging to subclade K. Public health experts attribute the surge to holiday travel, low vaccination rates, misinformation, and a partial vaccine mismatch. One pediatric flu-related death was reported in the latest week, bringing the season’s total to nine. Experts, including Eric Ascher of Northwell’s Lenox Hill Hospital, note that flu cases are under-reported and predict the peak will occur in at least another one to two weeks. Aaron Milstone of Johns Hopkins University cautioned against premature conclusions about the season’s trajectory.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 06, 2026 04:11 AM
Source:[KSL.com](https://www.ksl.com/article/51428543/cdc-says-2025-26-flu-season-moderately-severe-as-cases-hit-11-million)

**CDC Labels 2025-26 Flu Season 'Moderately Severe' With 11 million Illnesses So Far**
The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has classified the 2025-26 flu season as 'moderately severe,' estimating at least 11 million illnesses, 120,000 hospitalizations, and 5,000 deaths as of January 5, 2026. This marks a significant increase compared to the same period in the previous season, which saw 5.3 million illnesses, 63,000 hospitalizations, and 2,700 deaths. The dominant strain is Influenza A(H3N2), responsible for over 91% of subtyped influenza A cases, with 90.5% of characterized H3N2 viruses belonging to subclade K—a variant historically linked to more severe illness, especially among older adults and young children. Public health experts attribute the surge to lower vaccination rates, widespread misinformation about vaccines, and increased holiday travel. Hospital admissions rose sharply, with approximately 33,301 new flu-related admissions in the previous week alone. Outpatient visits for respiratory illness have reached 8.2%, exceeding the national baseline. The CDC predicts the peak will occur within the next one to two weeks, with flu activity expected to remain high for several more weeks. One pediatric flu death was reported last week, bringing the season’s total to nine. The CDC continues to urge the public to get vaccinated and take preventive measures.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 05, 2026 10:33 PM
Source:[The Sunday Guardian Live](https://sundayguardianlive.com/health/cdc-labels-2025-26-flu-season-moderately-severe-with-11-million-illnesses-so-far-163481/)

**5,000 deaths in 2025-26 across U.S. due to flu, warns CDC**
The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has classified the 2025-26 influenza season as 'moderately severe,' projecting at least 5,000 deaths, 120,000 hospitalizations, and 11 million illnesses. Influenza A(H3N2) remains the dominant strain, accounting for over 91% of subtyped influenza A cases, with 90.5% of 389 genetically characterized viruses belonging to the K subclade. Hospital admissions for influenza rose to 33,301 in the week ending December 27, 2025, and outpatient visits for respiratory illness reached 8.2%, exceeding seasonal baselines. One pediatric flu-related death was reported in the latest week, bringing the season’s total to nine. Public health experts attribute the surge to holiday travel, low vaccination rates, and misinformation. Despite a mismatch between the vaccine and circulating strains, the CDC notes that vaccination still reduces the risk of severe disease, with 130 million doses distributed in the U.S. this season. Flu activity is expected to persist for several weeks.
Original language: en
Publish date: January 05, 2026 07:10 PM

**US CDC says 2025-26 flu season 'moderately severe' as cases hit 11 million By Reuters**
The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) classified the 2025-26 flu season as 'moderately severe,' marking the first time such a designation has been made. According to CDC data released on January 5, 2026, seasonal influenza activity remained elevated and increased in the final week of December. The CDC estimates the season has caused at least 11 million illnesses, 120,000 hospitalizations, and 5,000 deaths. This compares to the 2024-25 season, which saw at least 5.3 million illnesses, 63,000 hospitalizations, and 2,700 deaths by December 28, 2024. Influenza A(H3N2) is the dominant strain, accounting for over 91% of subtyped influenza A cases, with 90.5% of 389 genetically characterized viruses belonging to subclade K. Hospital admissions for flu rose to about 33,301 in the week ending December 27, and outpatient visits for respiratory illness reached 8.2%, above seasonal baselines. One pediatric flu-related death was reported in the latest week, bringing the season’s total to nine. Public health experts cited holiday travel, low vaccination rates, and misinformation as contributing factors. Although a mismatch exists between the vaccine and circulating strains, the CDC emphasized that vaccination still reduces the risk of severe disease. Approximately 130 million flu vaccine doses have been distributed in the U.S. this season, and flu activity is expected to persist for several weeks.

**USA: CDC Classifies 2025-26 Flu Season as Moderate as Case Numbers Rise Significantly**
The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has classified the 2025-26 influenza season as 'moderate' based on data released on January 5, 2026. Since the last week of December 2025, influenza activity has increased significantly. The CDC estimates that the season has already caused at least 11 million cases, 120,000 hospitalizations, and 5,000 deaths—marking a substantial rise compared to the same period in 2024, when there were approximately 5.3 million cases, 63,000 hospitalizations, and 2,700 deaths. The dominant strain remains Influenza A(H3N2), accounting for over 91% of subtyped Influenza A cases. Of 389 Influenza A(H3N2) viruses genetically analyzed by the CDC since September 28, 2025, 90.5% belonged to the K subclade, a variant of A(H3N2). Hospitalization rates for flu patients reached approximately 33,301 in the week ending December 27, 2025, showing a sharp increase. Outpatient visits for respiratory illnesses rose to 8.2% of all visits, exceeding seasonal baseline levels. The CDC reported one additional pediatric flu-related death in the previous week, bringing the total number of child deaths in the 2025-26 season to nine. Health officials anticipate that flu activity will continue for several more weeks.

**Flu Activity Rises in December, CDC Classifies 2025-26 Season as Moderately Severe**
The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) has classified the 2025-26 influenza season as 'moderately severe,' citing a significant increase in seasonal flu activity during the final week of December. As of January 5, 2026, the CDC estimates that the season has caused at least 11 million infections, 120,000 hospitalizations, and 5,000 deaths—marking a substantial rise compared to the same period in the previous season, which recorded approximately 5.3 million cases, 63,000 hospitalizations, and 2,700 deaths by December 28, 2024. Influenza A(H3N2) remains the dominant strain, accounting for over 91% of subtyped influenza A cases. Of 389 genetically characterized A(H3N2) viruses collected between September 28, 2025, and the reporting date, 90.5% belonged to the K lineage. Hospitalizations due to influenza reached approximately 33,301 in the week ending December 27, 2025, showing a sharp increase from prior weeks. Outpatient visits for respiratory illnesses rose to 8.2% of all visits, surpassing seasonal baseline levels. The CDC reported one additional pediatric flu-related death in the past week, bringing the total pediatric fatalities for the season to nine. Health officials indicate that flu activity is expected to persist for several more weeks.

**US CDC says 2025-26 flu season 'moderately severe' as cases hit 11 million**
The U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) classified the 2025-26 flu season as 'moderately severe,' marking the first time such a designation has been made. According to CDC data, the season has already resulted in at least 11 million illnesses, 120,000 hospitalizations, and 5,000 deaths. This compares to the 2024-25 season, which saw an estimated 5.3 million illnesses, 63,000 hospitalizations, and 2,700 deaths by December 28, 2024. Influenza A(H3N2) remains the dominant strain, accounting for over 91% of subtyped influenza A cases, with 90.5% of 389 genetically characterized A(H3N2) viruses belonging to subclade K. Hospital admissions for influenza rose sharply to 33,301 in the week ended December 27, 2025, and outpatient visits for respiratory illness reached 8.2%, above seasonal baselines. Nine pediatric flu-related deaths have been reported so far in the 2025-26 season, including one in the most recent week. Public health experts attribute the surge to holiday travel, low vaccination rates, and misinformation. Despite a mismatch between the current flu vaccine and circulating strains, the CDC emphasized that vaccination still reduces the risk of severe disease. Approximately 130 million doses of flu vaccine have been distributed in the U.S. this season. Flu activity is expected to continue for several weeks.

**CDC projects moderate flu season: What to know**
The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) projects a moderate flu season for the United States during the 2025-2026 season, with hospitalization levels expected to be similar to those of the 2024-2025 season. Last year’s flu season was one of the most severe since 2010, with a hospitalization rate of 127.1 per 100,000 people, resulting in at least 47 million illnesses, 21 million healthcare visits, 610,000 hospitalizations, and 28,000 flu-related deaths according to preliminary CDC estimates. The CDC has never recorded two consecutive high-severity flu seasons in over 20 years of tracking, but acknowledges it is possible. Therefore, the agency forecasts a moderate impact across all age groups. Additionally, the CDC analyzed the Southern Hemisphere’s flu season (April–September 2025), which serves as a predictor for the Northern Hemisphere. The flu vaccine was 50.4% effective at preventing outpatient visits and 49.7% effective at preventing hospitalizations in the Southern Hemisphere. Since the 2025-2026 flu vaccine has the same composition as the one used in the Southern Hemisphere, the CDC suggests it 'might be similarly effective if the same viruses circulate in the coming season.'
